attributes.alt: Cover for Row, Row, Row Your Boat by Jane Cabrera. Cover shows a cat and a dog rowing a small boat down a stream as a tiger, crocodile, and elephant look on.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to build background and to introduce vocabulary
Begin Story Time by introducing the book and asking,
What do you say when you see someone you know?
Read for enjoyment and understanding, noticing how animals greet the dog and cat.
Join in singing, rhyming, and word play.
Show an awareness of new words and curiosity about their meaning.
Produce rhyming words; Identify rhyming words.
Sing, play musical instruments, and move to the rhythm in classroom activities.
Act out to recreate and retell stories, moods, or experiences.
Engage in movement sequences with adult prompts.
Show children pictures of different animals and have children decide if the cat and the dog saw these animals as they rowed down the stream.
Encourage children to move around like the  animals in the pictures.
How can we express ourselves through music and dance?
What music can you listen to? What books can you find about music and movement?
Pretend to play an instrument. What instrument is it?
What is something that sounds loud? How can you make a musical instrument sound different?
What’s your favorite way to express yourself?
Make a picture of yourself dancing.
What letter do you hear at the beginning of the word
Build something that you can use to sing into.

attributes.alt: Cover for Row, Row, Row Your Boat by Jane Cabrera. Cover shows a cat and a dog rowing a small boat down a stream as a tiger, crocodile, and elephant look on.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder show pride and introduce vocabulary
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to the book.
Read for enjoyment and understanding, noticing vocabulary words used in context.
Join in singing, rhyming, and word play.
Show an awareness of new words and curiosity about their meaning.
Use single words or phrases as appropriate.
Reframe the narrative in order to persist and self-motivate.
Produce rhyming words; Identify rhyming words.
Sing, play musical instruments, and move to the rhythm in classroom activities.
Invite children to look at pictures and guess what the person will be doing next.
Ask children to talk about how they know what’s next.
How can we express ourselves through music and dance?
What is your favorite song? How does it make you feel?
Pretend you are one of the characters in your book.
Can you make up a dance that has three moves?
Can you write or draw about how you feel when you express yourself with music or dance?
Can you draw a musical instrument?
Can you create a stage where characters might stand to sing and dance?

attributes.alt: Cover for Row, Row, Row Your Boat by Jane Cabrera. Cover shows a cat and a dog rowing a small boat down a stream as a tiger, crocodile, and elephant look on.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to share the comprehension skill and introduce vocabulary
Begin Story Time by introducing the book and asking,
What animals did the dog and cat meet along the way?
Read for enjoyment and understanding, noticing vocabulary in context.
Show an awareness of new words and curiosity about their meaning.
Use single words or phrases as appropriate
Produce rhyming words; Identify rhyming words.
Identify at least 20 uppercase and 20lowercase letters in text.
Sing, play musical instruments, and move to the rhythm in classroom activities.
Show interest and appreciation for other’s work; Use art for self-expression.
Show children picture cards of different items. Have children identify the items and then match  the ones that rhyme with each other.
Encourage children to find different rhyming words.
How can we express ourselves through music and dance?
Why do you sing and dance?
Pretend you are a famous dancer. How would you move?
Which instrument is louder than the others?
Do you like dancing or making music better? Why do you like expressing yourself this way?
Draw how your favorite song makes you feel.
What are the first two letters of the word
Can you make an instrument? What materials would you use?

attributes.alt: Big Chart of Big Ideas for Old MacDonald's Farm. Chart shows a horse, a cow, goats, ducks, chicks, and a chicken in front of a farmhouse.
Cover for Row, Row, Row Your Boat by Jane Cabrera. Cover shows a cat and a dog rowing a small boat down a stream as a tiger, crocodile, and elephant look on.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to build background and engage children with a song located on the Big Chart. introduce vocabulary
Begin Story Time by introducing the Big Chart and singing a familiar song.
Read for enjoyment and understanding, noticing characteristics of a farm.
Show awareness of new words and curiosity about their meaning.
Join in singing, rhyming, and word play.
Use single words or phrases as appropriate.
Sing, play musical instruments, and move to the rhythm in classroom activities.
Invite children to look at pictures of different animals and challenge them to classify the animals as farm animals or not farm animals.
Guide children to talk about the animals.
How can we express ourselves through music and dance?
Can you make a song using words from your book?
Pretend you are singing and dancing in a show for your friends and family.
Can you put the instruments in order from biggest to smallest?
Can you write or draw about what makes you want to dance?
Draw or paint a musical instrument.
What letters do you see in the words
What materials can you use to build a farm?

TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Row, Row, Row Your Boat by Jane Cabrera. Copyright © 2014 by Jane Cabrera. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Holiday House Publishing, Inc.

attributes.alt: Cover for Row, Row, Row Your Boat by Jane Cabrera. Cover shows a cat and a dog rowing a small boat down a stream as a tiger, crocodile, and elephant look on.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to build background, engage children with a book and song, and introduce vocabulary
Begin Story Time by introducing the book and asking,
How do music and dance help us learn?
Read for enjoyment and understanding, noticing vocabulary in context.
Join in singing, rhyming, and word play.
Show an awareness of new words and curiosity about their meaning; Understand and use a growing number of science words.
Use single words or phrases as appropriate
Reframe the narrative in order to persist and self-motivate.
Identify at least 20 uppercase and 20 lowercase letters in text.
Produce rhyming words; Identify rhyming words.
Convey meaning through marks, letters, or symbols.
Sing, play musical instruments, and move to the rhythm in classroom activities.
Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt:
How does music make you feel?
Save children’s writing to share and display.
How can we express ourselves through music and dance?
How would you dance to fast music? How would you dance to slow music?
Pretend you are performing your favorite song for your audience. What do you want to express to the audience?
Pick up an instrument. Can you make a long sound? Now make a short sound.
Write about how you express yourself through music and dance.
Can you create a drawing or painting that shows how you feel about your favorite song?
Show the letters you know in the words
Can you build a stage for tiny singers and dancers to perform?
